revision.comment: /* top */replace deprecated template parameters, removed: | slogan = Debunking email hoaxes and exposing Internet scams since 2003! using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Hoax Slayer | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://www.hoax-slayer.com/}} | commercial = | type = Debunking resource, reference pages | registration = | language = | num_users = | content_license = | programming language = | owner = Brett Christensen | author = | editor = | launch_date = August 2003 | revenue = $50,000/year (advertising)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/technology/digital-living/3098856/Aussie-hoax-slayer-smashes-web-scams | title=Aussie hoax slayer smashes web scams | work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] | date=26 November 2009 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Elliott, Tim}}</ref> | alexa = {{decrease}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/www.hoax-slayer.com 20,967] (Global, 05/2014) | ip = | current_status = Online }} '''Hoax-Slayer.com''' is a website established in 2003 by Brett Christensen, dedicated to critically analyzing the veracity of [[urban legend]]s. While it is best known for debunking false stories, it also hosts a page listing strange but true urban legends.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.news-mail.com.au/news/the-net-has-a-caped-crusader/425839/ | title=Brett Christensen a 'Hoax Slayer' | work=[[NewsMail]] | date=11 December 2009 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Wenzel, Murray}}</ref> It originated as a [[Yahoo!]] group before the website was established.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/10-things/top-10-sites-to-debunk-internet-hoaxes/#. | title=Top 10 sites to debunk Internet hoaxes | work=[[TechRepublic]] | date=6 August 2010 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Malone, Tim}}</ref> Stories it has debunked include fake videos claiming to depict [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/malaysia-airlines-mh370-found-in-the-bermuda-triangle-not-a-chance/ | title=Malaysia Airlines MH370 found in the Bermuda Triangle? Not a chance | work=[[CBS News]] | date=17 March 2014 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Ngak, Chenda}}</ref> myths that the 2013 [[supermoon]] appeared bigger than it really did,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/06/21/194250285/super-moon-to-dominate-weekend-sky | title=Supermoon To Dominate Weekend Sky | work=[[NPR]] | date=21 June 2013 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Neuman, Scott}}</ref> and a "Simon Ashton" hoax claiming that emails from Simon Ashton should not be opened because doing so will lead to your computer being hacked.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2010/mar/17/virus-warning-simon-ashton | title=Is the virus warning about a hacker called Simon Ashton real? | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=17 March 2010 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Arthur, Charles}}</ref> In 2014, the site was reworked, changing the style and color scheme for main pages and new reports, while old reports retained the previous style.
==Brett Christensen== Brett M. Christensen, a resident of [[Bundaberg]], [[Australia]], worked as a [[caravan park]] cleaner before he founded Hoax-Slayer.com in August 2003. He was inspired to do so after being convinced that the "Budweiser Frogs virus" really existed, only to discover later that it did not.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/hoax-slayer-puts-the-bite-on-vampires-of-the-cyber-world-20091125-jrwz.html | title=Hoax slayer puts the bite on vampires of the cyber world | work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=26 November 2009 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Elliott, Tim}}</ref> He writes most of the site's articles, but two of his three sons, according to him, "help maintain the website and do invaluable work behind the scenes."<ref>[http://www.hoax-slayer.com/about.html About Hoax Slayer]</ref> In addition to debunking hoaxes, Christensen has noted that many of them are "loosely derived" from real events. "For example, in Australia in 1999 a woman claimed to have been assaulted by criminals who used a chemical disguised as perfume to disable her. Warnings about that incident, which may not have been true to begin with, soon spread to the internet and have circulated ever since," he told the Guardian.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/jun/11/women.ukcrime | title=Beware of the hoax | work=The Guardian | date=10 June 2008 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Groskop, Viv}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Internet properties established in 2003]] [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Australian websites]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Fact-checking websites]]

{{Infobox company | name = Intelitek, Inc. | logo = | type = | predecessor = | successor = | founder = | defunct = | fate = | area_served = | key_people = Ido Yerushalmi (CEO) | industry = STEM education and Technology education | genre = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | caption = | foundation = 1982 | location_city = [[Derry, New Hampshire]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = | locations = | homepage = http://intelitek.com }}
'''Intelitek''' is a privately held [[technology education]] company focused on STEM education, Robotics, Programming and technology training for machining, manufacturing, industrial maintenance and more. Based in [[Derry, New Hampshire]], the company was established in 1982 and in July 2001 adopted the name Intelitek, Inc.<ref name="businessweek">{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=1479063 |title=Intelitek, Inc.: Private Company Information |publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=August 6, 2011 |accessdate=October 7, 2011}}</ref> The company has customers in [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]], the [[Middle East]], and [[Australia]], in the fields of secondary education, colleges and universities, and industrial training centers.<ref name=businessweek /> Intelitek offers educational solutions for: STEM Education, Engineering, Robotics, Advanced Manufacturing, Automation, Industrial Maintenance, Oil and Gas, Process Control, Agriculture.
[[File:ER4u.jpg|thumb|The SCORBOT-ER 4u educational robot.]]
One of Intelitek's latest releases is an online learning environment, to learn how to program virtual and real robots within the STEM pathways.
==Installations and sponsorships== In 2002, Intelitek provided a $350,000 grant to [[Gilbert High School (Arizona)|Gilbert High School]], installing a state-of-the-art robotics lab in the school's former wood shop. This was the first such high school robotics lab in the state of Arizona.<ref>{{cite news |title=Robotics lab finds home in Gilbert |author= Lindsey Collom |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/azcentral/access/1839456131.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+08%2C+2002&author=Lindsey+Collom&pub=Arizona+Republic&desc=ROBOTICS+LAB+FINDS+HOME+IN+GILBERT |newspaper=[[The Arizona Republic]] |date=February 8, 2002 |accessdate=October 7, 2011}}</ref>
In 2007, the Deputy Prime Minister of [[Russia]], [[Sergei Ivanov]], visited the [[Ufa State Aviation Technical University]] to tour an educational "Technopark" stocked with sophisticated equipment. One of the key features of the facility was a [[Lathe (metal)#CNC lathe / CNC turning center|mini-CNC lathe]] purchased from Intelitek. The Technopark was Russia's only facility to have this level of equipment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bashinform.ru/news/151745/ |title=Sergei Ivanov visits the "Technopark" of aviation technology |author=Love Kolokolova |date=June 27, 2007 |work= |publisher=Bashinform (Башинформ) news service |accessdate=October 7, 2011}}</ref>
Intelitek was a supporting sponsor of the 2011 [[VEX Robotics Competition]] World Championship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sys-con.com/node/1797853 |title=United States, Canada, China and New Zealand Teams Reign Supreme at the VEX Robotics World Championship |author=Business Wire |date=April 18, 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Business Wire]] |accessdate=October 7, 2011}}</ref> And the company's executives also serve as mentors to students in a high school's "Project Lead The Way" program in the headquarters' area.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dover High School Tech Center achieves Project Lead the Way certification |author= |url=http://www.fosters.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100928/GJCOMMUNITY_01/709289851/-1/FOSNEWS |newspaper=[[Foster's Daily Democrat]] |date=September 28, 2010 |accessdate=October 7, 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Companies based in New Hampshire]] [[Category:Companies established in 1982]] [[Category:Educational robots]] [[Category:Robotics companies of the United States]] [[Category:1982 establishments in New Hampshire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Joseph G. McKenna, [[Congregation of Christian Brothers|CFC]] | office = 5th President of [[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]] | honorific-prefix = '''[[Brother (Christian)|Brother]]''' | predecessor = [[Richard B. Power]], CFC | successor = [[John G. Driscoll]], CFC | termend = 1971 | termstart = 1965 | office2 = Dean of [[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]] | office1 = Vice President of [[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]] | president1 = [[Richard B. Power]], CFC | termend1 = 1965 | termstart1 = 1963 | termend2 = 1957 | termstart2 = 1952 | birth_date = 1922 | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = 28 July 1973 (aged 51) | death_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], United States | alma_mater = [[Fordham University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[Columbia University]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) | religion = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] }} '''Joseph Gonzaga McKenna''', [[Congregation of Christian Brothers|CFC]] (1922 – 28 July 1973) was an [[United States|American]] educator and member of the [[Congregation of Christian Brothers]], a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[religious institute]]. He served as the fifth President of [[Iona College (New York)|Iona College]] in [[New Rochelle, New York|New Rochelle]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. == Early life and education == McKenna was born in 1922 in New York City, where he was raised with a sister, Mary.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/07/30/archives/joseph-g-mkenna-iona-expresident.html|title=JOSEPH G. M'KENNA, IONA EX‐PRESIDENT|last=Times|first=Special To The New York|date=1973-07-30|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-11}} He joined the [[Congregation of Christian Brothers]] in 1936 at the age of 14. In 1951 he graduated from [[Fordham University]] with a [[master's degree]], and received a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1955 from [[Columbia University]]. He additionally earned a bachelor's degree and a second master's. == Academic career == After graduating college, [[Brother (Christian)|Brother]] McKenna began teaching at [[All Hallows High School|All Hallows Institute]] in 1942, and later taught at [[Rice High School (Manhattan, New York)|Rice High School]], [[Iona Preparatory School]], and [[Power Memorial Academy]] over the next eight years. In 1950, he became a mathematics professor at Iona College, and two years later was appointed [[Dean (education)|dean]] of the college. He served in that capacity until 1957, when he left New York to found [[Catholic Memorial School|Catholic Memorial High School]] in [[West Roxbury]], [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], the first Christian Brothers school in [[New England]]. He served as principal there until 1963. === President of Iona College === McKenna returned to Iona College in 1963, and served there as vice president until 1965, when he became the college's 5th president.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iona.edu/About/Office-of-the-President/Past-Presidents.aspx|title=Iona College – About: Office of the President|website=www.iona.edu|access-date=2016-11-15}} Under his leadership, the college notably changed from an [[Men's colleges in the United States|all-male institution]] to a [[Mixed-sex education|coeducational]] college.{{Cite news|url=http://news.hrvh.org/veridian/cgi-bin/senylrc?a=d&d=bronxvillereviewpressreporterBRONXVILLE19681128.1.5#|title=The Feminine Touch To Be Added At Iona|last=|first=|date=28 November 1968|work=The Bronxville Review Press Reporter|access-date=13 November 2016|via=HRHV Historical Newspapers}} The decision, made by the college's board of trustees, was announced by McKenna in November 1968. The change in policy, which would take effect with the first female students entering Iona as freshmen in September 1969, was explained by McKenna in a press release:
The change is not as drastic as one may assume. The entrance of women into the other divisions of Iona that took place during the past four years was preparing the college, whether we realized it or not, for the recent decision of the board."
The decision for Iona to adopt coeducation was part of a national trend, with 62 single-sex colleges going coed in 1968 alone. Within the Iona and regional communities, the change was met with mixed but mostly positive reactions. The mayor of New Rochelle, where the college is located, expressed his approval, as did several Iona professors, and students. McKenna's predecessor as President of Iona College, Br. Richard B. Power, said, "While I do not like to see Iona become a coeducational institution, I can understand the decision of the board of trustees and I look forward with interest to this latest development in the history of the college." Additionally, the representative of the junior class express student acceptance of the decision, while noting the possible lack of sufficient space to house female boarders. In 1971, McKenna resigned as president due to ill health, but continued to teach graduate students in the school of business. In addition to his work at Iona College, he also served as assistant to the superior of the Eastern American Province of the Congregation of Christian Brothers. == Death and legacy == McKenna died on Saturday, 28 July 1973 of a heart attack while on vacation in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], at the age of 51. McKenna's legacy is continued through the Brother Joseph G. McKenna Memorial Award for Academic Excellence, presented annually by the faculty of Iona College's Hagan School of Business.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iona.edu/iona/media/Documents/Student%20Life/Activities/2014-commencement-book.pdf|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKenna, Joseph G.}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:1973 deaths]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:American university and college presidents]] [[Category:Burials in New York (state)]] [[Category:Business educators]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Congregation of Christian Brothers]] [[Category:Deaths from disease]] [[Category:Disease-related deaths in California]] [[Category:Educators from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Educators from New York City]] [[Category:Fordham University alumni]] [[Category:Founders of schools in the United States]] [[Category:Iona College faculty]] [[Category:Mathematics educators]] [[Category:Roman Catholic religious brothers]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]]

{{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox economist | name = Joshua Angrist | school_tradition = | color = | image = Angrist, Josh Fall2015.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|9|18|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | institution = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | field = [[Econometrics]], [[labour economics]] | alma_mater = [[Princeton University]]
[[Oberlin College]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Orley Ashenfelter]] | contributions = | awards = | spouse = | signature = | repec_prefix = e | repec_id = pan29 }} '''Joshua David Angrist''' (born September 18, 1960http://nla.gov.au/anbd.aut-an35816925) is an [[Israeli American]] [[Economics|economist]]. He is Ford Professor of Economics at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].{{cite web|title= MIT Economics: Joshua Angrist|url=http://economics.mit.edu/faculty/angrist|accessdate=11 May 2011}} Angrist has taught at the university level since 1989. He is known for his use of quasi-experimental research designs (such as [[instrumental variables]]) to study the effects of public policies and changes in economic or social circumstances. Angrist has also made contributions in theoretical [[econometrics]]. He co-founded and serves as a director of the [http://seii.mit.edu School Effectiveness & Inequality Initiative] based within the [[MIT Department of Economics]].{{cite web|title= School Effectiveness & Inequality Initiative: Joshua Angrist|url=http://seii.mit.edu/people/joshua-angrist/|date=11 May 2012}} The center's work focuses on the economics of education, issues surrounding domestic poverty, and the connections between human capital and the [[Income inequality in the United States|American income distribution]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Columbus, Ohio]] and raised in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], Angrist attended [[Oberlin College]], where he received his B.A. in economics in 1982. He lived in [[Israel]] from 1982 until 1985. Angrist received his [[Ph.D.]] in Economics from [[Princeton University]] in 1989. His doctoral dissertation, "Econometric Analysis of the [[Draft lottery (1969)|Vietnam Era Draft Lottery]]," was supervised by [[Orley Ashenfelter]] and later published in parts in the ''[[American Economic Review]]''.{{cite journal |last=Angrist |first=Joshua D. |year=1990 |title=Lifetime Earnings and the Vietnam Era Draft Lottery: Evidence from Social Security Administrative Records |journal=American Economic Review |volume=80 |issue=3 |pages=313–336 |jstor=2006669 }} Angrist was an assistant professor at [[Harvard University]] from 1989 until 1991, when he returned to Israel as a senior lecturer at [[Hebrew University]].{{cite web|title= Curriculum Vitae: Joshua D.Angrist|url=http://econ-www.mit.edu/faculty/angrist/cv|accessdate=10 June 2011}} Angrist holds dual US-Israeli citizenship.{{cite web|title=NBER Profile: Joshua Angrist|url=http://www.nber.org/reporter/summer03/profiles.html|publisher=National Bureau of Economic Research|accessdate=10 June 2011}} Since 1996 Angrist has been a faculty member in the Department of Economics at MIT, where he teaches [[econometrics]] and [[labor economics]]. He lives in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]]. ==Affiliations and honors== In addition to teaching at MIT, Angrist is a research associate at the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] and a Research Fellow at the [[Institute for the Study of Labor]] (IZA).{{cite web|title= NBER: Joshua Angrist|url=http://www.nber.org/programs/ed/ed-mem.html|accessdate=11 May 2012}} He is also a fellow of the [[Econometric Society]]. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2006.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter A|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterA.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=18 April 2011}} In 2007 Angrist received an honorary doctorate in Economics from the [[University of St. Gallen]].http://www.unisg.ch/en/Schools/Economics+and+Political+Science/Ueber+SEPS/Dozierende/Ehrendoktorate.aspx He is the recipient of the 2011 [[John von Neumann Award]] given annually by the [[Rajk László College for Advanced Studies]] in Budapest. ==Publications== In 2009 Angrist published ''Mostly Harmless Econometrics'', co-authored with [[Jörn-Steffen Pischke]]. This book explores econometric tools used by empirical researchers.{{cite web|url=http://www.mostlyharmlesseconometrics.com/book-contents/|publisher=Princeton University Press|accessdate=11 May 2012|title=Mostly Harmless Econometrics}} In 2014, Angrist and Pischke released ''Mastering 'Metrics: The Path from Cause to Effect'', targeted at undergraduate econometrics students. Angrist has authored and coauthored dozens of scientific papers and reports. ==See also== * [[Maimonides' Rule]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * http://econ-www.mit.edu/faculty/angrist/index.htm * http://www.nber.org/people/joshua_angrist * http://www.iza.org/index_html?lang=en&mainframe=http%3A//www.iza.org/iza/en/webcontent/personnel/photos/index_html%3Fkey%3D48&topSelect=personnel&subSelect=fellows {{John von Neumann Award recipients}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Angrist, Joshua}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Brookline, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Economists from Ohio]][[Category:Economists from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Labor economists]] [[Category:Education economists]] [[Category:Microeconometricians]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:21st-century economists]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Fellows of the Econometric Society]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:Oberlin College alumni]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox scientist | birth_name = Linda Susanne Howarth | image = Linda Gottfredson ISIR Distinguished Contributor Interview.jpg | image_size = | caption = Linda Gottfredson interviewed in 2016 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|06|24}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco]] | residence = | citizenship = American | ethnicity = | field = [[Educational psychology]] | work_institution = [[University of Delaware]], editorial boards of ''[[Intelligence (journal)|Intelligence]]'', ''[[Learning and Individual Differences]]'', and ''[[Society (journal)|Society]]'' | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]], [[Johns Hopkins University]] | thesis_title = The relation of situs of work to occupational achievement | thesis_url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/302830739/F8ABC2D4FD90412FPQ/1?accountid=12948 | thesis_year = 1977 | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = ''[[Mainstream Science on Intelligence]]'' | prizes = }} '''Linda Susanne Gottfredson''' (née '''Howarth'''; born June 24, 1947) is an American psychologist and writer. She is professor emeritus of [[educational psychology]] at the [[University of Delaware]] and co-director of the Delaware-[[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]] Project for the Study of Intelligence and Society. Gottfredson's work has been influential in shaping U.S. public and private policies regarding [[affirmative action]], hiring quotas, and "[[race-norming]]" on aptitude tests.{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/19/weekinreview/the-nation-race-norming-tests-becomes-a-fiery-issue.html |title=The Nation; 'Race Norming' Tests Becomes a Fiery Issue |last=Kilborn |first=Peter T. |website=The New York Times |publication-date=19 May 1991}} She is on the boards of the [[International Society for the Study of Individual Differences]] (ISSID), the [[International Society for Intelligence Research]] (ISIR), and the editorial boards of the scientific journals ''[[Intelligence (journal)|Intelligence]]'', ''[[Learning and Individual Differences]]'', and ''[[Society (journal)|Society]]''. Gottfredson has received research grants worth $267,000 from the [[Pioneer Fund]], an organization which has been described as "racist" and "white supremacist".Avner Falk. Anti-semitism: a history and psychoanalysis of contemporary hatred. Abc-Clio, 2008, pg. 18{{cite journal |title=U. Delaware Reaches Accord On Race Studies |first1=Ron |last1=Kaufman |journal=The Scientist |volume=6 |issue=14 |pages=1 |date=July 6, 1992 |url=https://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/12397/title/U--Delaware-Reaches-Accord-On-Race-Studies/ }}{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/2962466 |jstor=2962466 |title=The Pioneer Fund: Bankrolling the Professors of Hate |journal=[[The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education]] |issue=6 |pages=58–61 |year=1994 |last1=Miller |first1=Adam }} ==Life and work== Gottfredson was born in [[San Francisco]] on June 24th, 1947. She is a third generation university faculty member. Her father, Jack A. Howarth (died 2006), was a faculty at [[University of California, Davis|U.C. Davis]] School of Veterinary Medicine, as was his father.{{Cite web|url=https://senate.universityofcalifornia.edu/_files/inmemoriam/html/jackhowrath.html|title=Jack Howrath|website=senate.universityofcalifornia.edu|access-date=2018-09-23}}{{Cite journal|last=Wainer|first=Howard|last2=Robinson|first2=Daniel H.|date=September 2009|title=Linda S. Gottfredson|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2F10.3102%2F1076998609339366|journal=Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics|language=en|volume=34|issue=3|pages=395–427|doi=10.3102/1076998609339366|issn=1076-9986}} Gottfredson initially majored in biology, but later transferred to psychology with her first husband, [[Gary Don Gottfredson]]. They received bachelor's degrees in psychology in 1969 from [[University of California, Berkeley]], then worked in the [[Peace Corps]] in [[Malaysia]] until 1972. She also taught in schools for the disadvantaged for a time when she was young.[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0765804972&id=VLtTKixjfYQC&pg=PA97&]{{full|date=September 2018}} They both went to graduate school at [[Johns Hopkins University]], where she received a Ph.D. in sociology in 1977. Gottfredson took a position at Hopkins' Center for Social Organization of Schools and investigated issues of occupational segregation and typology based on skill sets and intellectual capacity. She married [[Robert A. Gordon]], who worked in a related area at Hopkins, and they divorced by the mid-90s.[http://www.jhu.edu/~gazette/1994/nov2894/gordon.html]{{full|date=September 2018}} In 1985, Gottfredson participated in a conference called "The [[General intelligence factor|g Factor]] in Employment Testing". The papers presented were published in the December 1986 issue of the ''[[Journal of Vocational Behavior]]'', which she edited. In 1986, Gottfredson was appointed Associate Professor of Educational Studies at the [[University of Delaware]], Newark. In 1989, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that one of Gottfredson's presentations was cited favorably by an article in the [[National Association for the Advancement of White People]]'s magazine.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1989/11/16/pioneer-funds-controversial-projects/0f05cde6-6586-462d-acfa-cfd3ae65567e/ |title=PIONEER FUND'S CONTROVERSIAL PROJECTS |last=ANDERSON |first=JACK |date=1989-11-16 |work=Washington Post |access-date=2017-12-24 |last2=ATTA |first2=DALE VAN |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}} That year, she presented a series of papers on general [[intelligence]] factor and employment. Gottfredson has said:
We now have out there what I call the egalitarian fiction that all groups are equal in intelligence. We have social policy based on that fiction. For example, the [[1991 Civil Rights Act]] codified ''Griggs vs. Duke Power'', which said that if you have disproportionate hiring by race, you are prima facie -- that's prima facie evidence of racial discrimination. ...Differences in intelligence have real world effects, whether we think they're there or not, whether we want to wish them away or not. And we don't do anybody any good, certainly not the low-IQ people, by denying that those problems exist.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110525184528/http://aad.english.ucsb.edu/docs/PBS-oct94.htm "Race, IQ, Success and Charles Murray"]
She was promoted to full professor at the University of Delaware in 1990. In 1992, after two and a half years of debate and protest, the University of Delaware's administration reached a settlement that once again allowed Gottfredson and [[Jan Blits]] to continue receiving research funding from the Pioneer Fund.{{Cite web |url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/12397/title/U--Delaware-Reaches-Accord-On-Race-Studies/ |title=U. Delaware Reaches Accord On Race Studies |last=Kaufman |first=Ron |website=The Scientist |publication-date=6 July 1992}} Gottfredson's research and views have stirred considerable controversy, especially her testimony on public affirmative action policy and her defense of ''[[The Bell Curve]],'' in particular a statement she wrote, ''[[Mainstream Science on Intelligence]]'', which was signed by 51 colleagues and published in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]].''Gottfredson, Linda (December 13, 1994). [[Mainstream Science on Intelligence]]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', p. A18. Since then, she has written a number of articles on [[race and intelligence]], especially as it applies to occupational qualification. Gottfredson has been very critical of psychologist [[Robert Sternberg]], arguing against his position that there is a "[[practical intelligence]]" that is separate from the "analytical intelligence" measured by [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] tests.{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/03/science/scientist-at-work-robert-sternberg-his-goal-making-intelligence-tests-smarter.html |title=His Goal: Making Intelligence Tests Smarter |last=Goode |first=Erica |website=The New York Times |publication-date=3 April 2001}} ==Honors== * George A Miller Award (for outstanding journal article across specialty areas), Society for General Psychology, [[American Psychological Association]], 2008[http://www.udel.edu/udaily/2009/jan/gottfredson012209.html "University Press Release on Award"] * Fellow, Association for Psychological Science, elected 1998[http://www.psychologicalscience.org/fellows/fellows-new.cfm "List of Fellows from APS-website"] * Johns Hopkins University Society of Scholars, elected 1995[http://web.jhu.edu/commencement/honorees/scholall.html "List of scholars"] * Fellow, American Psychological Association, elected 1994 * [[Fellow]], [[Society for Industrial and {{For|the Spanish hard rock group|Sex Museum (band)}} [[Image:Museum of Sex by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|New York City's [[Museum of Sex]]]] A '''sex museum''' is a [[museum]] that displays [[erotic art]], historical [[sexual aid]]s, and documents on the history of [[erotica]]. They were popular in Europe at the end of the 1960s and during the 1970s, the era of the [[sexual revolution]]. Since the 1990s, these museums are often called '''erotic museums''' or '''erotic art museums''' instead of sex museums.
== Notable sex museums ==
=== North America === * The [[Museum of Sex]] in [[New York City]] opened in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museumofsex.com/|title=Museum of Sex - NYC|author=|date=|website=MoSEX|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> * The [[Hollywood Erotic Museum]] in [[Hollywood]] opened in January 2004. This museum is currently closed and now contains a [[Frederick's of Hollywood]] retail shop.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theeroticmuseum.com/|title=The Erotic Museum|author=|date=|website=www.theeroticmuseum.com|accessdate=21 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170528232102/http://theeroticmuseum.com/|archivedate=28 May 2017|df=}}</ref> *The [[World Erotic Art Museum]] in [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]] opened on October 16, 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weam.com/|title=WEAM - World Erotic Art Museum - WEAM - World Erotic Art Museum|author=|date=|website=www.weam.com|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> *The [[Erotic Heritage Museum]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] opened on August 3, 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://living-las-vegas.com/2008|title=2008 - Living Las Vegas|author=|date=|website=Living Las Vegas|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> It claims to be the "worlds largest erotic museum at 24,000 sq. ft.". * The [[Leather Archives & Museum]] in [[Chicago]] opened in 1991, and its current location features 10,000 square feet of exhibit space on two levels, a 164-seat auditorium, and a 600 square foot non-lending library. The [[LA&M]]<ref>[[Leather Archives and Museum]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=May 2017}} is the only museum in the world solely dedicated to BDSM/fetish/kink.
=== Europe === *[[Sexmuseum Amsterdam]] opened in 1985. *The [[Museum of Eroticism]] in [[Paris]] opened in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musee-erotisme.com|title=Document sans nom|author=|date=|website=www.musee-erotisme.com|accessdate=21 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170625191020/http://musee-erotisme.com/|archivedate=25 June 2017|df=}}</ref> * The [[Erotic Art Museum (Hamburg)|Erotic Art Museum]] near the [[Reeperbahn]] in [[Hamburg]] opened in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eroticartmuseum.de/|title=Erotic Art Museum Hamburg|first=|last=|date=|website=www.eroticartmuseum.de|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> * The [[Beate Uhse Erotic Museum]] in [[Berlin]] opened in 1996 and closed in 2014. It claimed to be "the world's largest erotic museum".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berlin.de/museumsfuehrer/00037.html |title=Beate Uhse Erotik-Museum |access-date=11 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050828182028/http://www.berlin.de/museumsfuehrer/00037.html |archive-date=28 August 2005 |dead-url=unfit}}</ref> * The [[Museum Erotica]] in [[Copenhagen]] opened in 1993.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum-erotica.dk/|title=Museum-Erotica|author=|date=|website=Museum Erotica|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> It was closed in 2009 due to financial problems. * The [[Museo de la Erotica]] in [[Barcelona]] opened in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erotica-museum.com/|title=Erotic Museum of Barcelona|first=|last=|date=|website=www.erotica-museum.com|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> * The first [[Russia]]n sex museum opened in 2004 in [[Saint Petersburg]]; it claims to exhibit the preserved penis of [[Rasputin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waytorussia.net/news/2004-04/russian-sex-museum.html|title=The First Russian Sex Museum will Exhibit Rasputin’s Penis|author=|date=7 August 2009|website=waytorussia.net|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> * While not itself a sex museum, the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum|National Archaeological Museum]] in [[Naples]] opened its extensive collection of historic erotic art in its [[Secret Museum, Naples|Secret Cabinet]] to the public in 2000. Most of the exhibits are from Greek and Roman times, and many were recovered from nearby [[Pompeii]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://archives.cnn.com/2000/STYLE/arts/08/01/erotic.art/ | work=CNN | title=Naples museum exposes public to ancient erotica | accessdate=May 23, 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518082231/http://archives.cnn.com/2000/STYLE/arts/08/01/erotic.art/ | archivedate=May 18, 2009 | df= }}</ref> * The [[Museo d'Arte Erotica]], devoted to the erotic history of Venice and showing historical and contemporary erotic art opened in [[Venice]], [[Italy]] in February 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museodarteerotica.it|title=museodarteerotica.it|author=|date=|website=www.museodarteerotica.it|accessdate=21 July 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722042639/http://www.museodarteerotica.it/|archivedate=22 July 2011|df=}}</ref> * The [[Secretum (British Museum)|Secretum]] or Cupboard 55, containing erotic objects at the [[British Museum]], [[London]]. * The [[Sex Machines Museum]] in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]], contains "an exposition of mechanical erotic appliances, the purpose of which is to bring pleasure and allow extraordinary and unusual positions during intercourse." On display in the museum are "more than 200 objects and mechanical appliances on view, a gallery of art with erotic themes, a cinema with old erotic films, erotic clothing and many other things pertaining to human sexuality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sexmachinesmuseum.com/en_page.html |title=SexMachinesMuseum |publisher=SexMachinesMuseum |date=1997-02-26 |accessdate=2013-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523070636/http://www.sexmachinesmuseum.com/en_page.html |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }}</ref> * The first erotic museum in [[Lithuania]] opened in [[Kaunas]] on 13 July 2009. *[[Athens]]'s first sex museum, the [[Greek Erotica Museum]], opened in the center Omonoia Kapodistriou 44 in 2012.<ref>url=http://www.eroticamuseum.gr {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222221519/http://www.eroticamuseum.gr/ |date=2012-02-22 }}</ref> *[[Moscow]]'s first sex museum, named "Tochka G" ('G Spot') opened in 2011.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2011/jul/12/moscow-sex-museum | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Art and design, Art (visual arts only), World news, Russia (News), Life and style, Sex (Life & style), Culture, South and Central Asia (News) | date=July 12, 2011}}</ref> *The Erotic Museum in [[Warsaw]], the first sex museum in [[Poland]], opened in 2011 with over 2,000 exhibits. It reveals the erotic fascinations of artists from all continents.<ref name="muzeumerotyki">{{en icon}} {{cite web |author=|url=http://muzeumerotyki.com/index.php?lang=en |title=Museum history |work=muzeumerotyki.com |publisher=|pages=|page=|date=|accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> The museum closed at the beginning of 2012 as they searched for a new location and more funds to keep the museum afloat.
===Asia=== [[File:鉄輪温泉秘宝館PB060105.jpg|thumb|"Beppu Hihōkan", a sex museum next to the Shiraike-Jigoku in the Kannawa Spa, [[Beppu, Ōita]], [[Japan]].]] *The first sex museum in [[China]] opened in 1999 in the center of [[Shanghai]]; in 2001 it moved to the outskirts of the city. It was variously called "Museum of Ancient Chinese Sex Culture" or "Dalin Cultural Exhibition" after its founder, [[sexology|sexologist]] Dr. [[Liu Dalin]]. In early 2004 it moved again, to [[Tong Li, Suzhou|Tong Li]], and is now known as the [[China Sex Museum]], with over three thousand erotic artifacts.<ref>[http://travel.discovery.com/news/afp/20031006/shanghai.html Travel Channel - Error<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051118001916/http://travel.discovery.com/news/afp/20031006/shanghai.html |date=2005-11-18 }}</ref><ref>[http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/CSM/index.htm China Sex Museum<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050818124300/http://www2.hu-berlin.de/sexology/CSM/index.htm |date=2005-08-18 }}</ref> *[[India]]'s first sex museum opened in [[Mumbai]] (Bombay) in 2002.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/2514387.stm | work=BBC News | title=India's first sex museum | date=November 26, 2002 | accessdate=May 23, 2010 | first=Monica | last=Chadha}}</ref> *[[South Korea]]'s first sex museum, [[Asia Eros Museum]], opened in the Insadong neighborhood in [[Seoul]] in 2003. The museum has since closed.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2934948.stm | work=BBC News | title=Sex museum opens in Seoul | date=May 24, 2003 | accessdate=May 23, 2010 | first=Caroline | last=Gluck}}</ref> *[[Love Land (South Korea)|Love Land]] Park on [[Jeju Island]], [[South Korea]] opened in 2004. It is an outdoor sculpture park focused on a theme of sex, running sex education films, and featuring 140 sculptures representing humans in various sexual positions. *In [[Japan]], there are many sex museums called "Hihokan (House of Hidden Treasures)" everywhere across the country. They are located in amusement centers in popular sightseeing spots or [[destination spa|spa]] resorts, and usually ran by individuals, not by organizations. They date back to the 1960s–70s; more recently such type of amusement resorts for elder men have declined, and mostly personal sex museums closed in the 1990s-2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chowchow.gr.jp/inova/atami/atami.html|title=熱海秘宝館|author=|date=|website=www.chowchow.gr.jp|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chowchow.gr.jp/inova/kinugawa/kinu.html|title=鬼怒川秘宝殿|author=|date=|website=www.chowchow.gr.jp|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chowchow.gr.jp/inova/toba/tobaj.html|title=鳥羽SF未来館|author=|date=|website=www.chowchow.gr.jp|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chowchow.gr.jp/inova/ise/ise.html|title=元祖国際秘宝館|author=|date=|website=www.chowchow.gr.jp|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chowchow.gr.jp/inova/beppu/index.html|title=別府秘宝館|author=|date=|website=www.chowchow.gr.jp|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref>
===Australia=== *The small [[National Museum of Erotica]] in [[Canberra]] opened in 2001. The museum closed soon after, although the collection continued to grow.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Museum of Erotica|url=http://www.bodypolitics.com.au/bpmuseum.html|website=Body politics home page|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref>
===Online=== * [http://www.venusberg.com The Venusberg Erotic Art-Museum] is a virtual Erotic-Museum, founded 1997 by a German collector and run as a [[paysite]]. * [http://vintage.eroticvisions.eu Vintage Erotica Museum] is a virtual Erotic Art Museum, online since 2007 and run as a [[paysite]]. * [http://muzeumerotyzmu.pl The Virtual Museum of Erotic Art] was created as a diploma work in the [[Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts]], [[Poland]]. The [[Adobe Flash]] based site is available in Polish and English. It is a collection of 69 erotic art works by prominent artists commented with selected quotes on the subject of [[eroticism]]. [[Image:Octave Uzanne-L'Eventail-1882.jpg|trumb|right|175px|[[Octave Uzanne]]-L'Eventail-1882]]
== See also == *[[Icelandic Phallological Museum]]

{{Infobox person | name = Maria Franck | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Maria Kristina Franck | birth_date = 2 February 1771 | birth_place = Uppsala, [[Sweden]] | death_date = 17 April 1847 | death_place = Stockholm, [[Sweden]] | othername = Kristina Ruckman (after 1808) | website = | spouse = Johan Gustav Ruckman }}
'''Maria Kristina Franck''' (2 February 1771 – 17 April 1847) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[actress]] and drama teacher. She was a member of the pioneer generation of the [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]], and belonged to the first stars of the theater. She has been referred to as her country's first native dramatic [[tragedienne]]. She was the principal of the theatre school ''[[Dramatens elevskola]]'' in 1819-23. During her last years on stage, she was known under her name as married, Ruckman.
== Life ==
Maria Franck was the daughter of a bricklayer journeyman, Johan Franck, and Brita Lundström.
In 1784, she was enrolled as a student of the [[Royal Swedish Opera]]. Her mentors where [[Marie Louise Marcadet]] and [[Jacques Marie Boutet|Monvel]], members of the [[French Theater of Gustav III|French theatre]]. Monvel where reportedly impressed by her talent and she was trained as an actress exclusively for speaking drama and not as a singer of opera.
===Career===
In 1788, Maria Franck was contracted as a "First actress" of the Royal Dramatic Theatre, which was founded that year. She was as such also a member of the actors board of directors, which managed the theater until 1803.<ref>Henrikson, Alf, Fram till Nybroplan: om Kungliga Dramatiska teatern, Wiken, Höganäs, 1988 {{ISBN|91-7024-445-6}} (in Swedish)</ref>
Maria Franck achieved great success foremost as a tragedienne, and as such, she has been referred to as the most important link between her mentor, the tragedinne Marie Louise Marcadet, and the famous tragedienne of the 19th-century Swedish theater, [[Sara Torsslow]].<ref>M Christina Ruckman, urn:sbl:6972, Svenskt biografiskt lexikon (art av Ingeborg Nordin Hennel), hämtad 2018-06-08.</ref> She did occasionally play comedy as well, and one of her most acclaimed roles was as Mrs Dorsan in Den svartsjuka hustrun ('Jealous Wife') by [[Desforges]]. She also performed an occasional minor singing part at the opera, as the staff of the Royal theaters (the Royal Swedish Opera and the Royal Dramatic Theatre) was formally available for both stages. She is known to have made occasional tours in the country. During the regency government years of Gustav IV Adolf (1792–96), she had rose to become one of the most valuable members of the Royal Dramatic Theatre, which is illustrated by the fact that her income from the theater belonged to the elite of the actresses there.<ref>M Christina Ruckman, urn:sbl:6972, Svenskt biografiskt lexikon (art av Ingeborg Nordin Hennel), hämtad 2018-06-08.</ref> Franck enjoyed great respect as an artist, and the theater director G F Åkerhjelm respectfully noted her "enlightened and experienced judgement" as well as her "excellent ability and her well deserved fame".<ref>M Christina Ruckman, urn:sbl:6972, Svenskt biografiskt lexikon (art av Ingeborg Nordin Hennel), hämtad 2018-06-08.</ref> She reportedly acted with a deep feeling and intensity, and a control over her [[mimic]], which was never melodramatic.
Her career lasted longer than most actors of her generation: most of her generation of actors retired after the 1809-10 season, while she remained until 1818. During her last years on the stage, she was criticized for being to melodramatic in her way of acting; she acted in accordance with the French school, which had by then became unfashionable. In 1818, she retired with a full pension.
Maria Franck had, in parallel with her acting career, given lessons in [[declamation]], and in 1819, the year following her retirement from the stage, she was engaged as the principal of the acting school ''[[Dramatens elevskola]]'', a position she kept until 1823. She is known as the mentor of [[Sara Torsslow]] and [[Charlotta Eriksson]].
In 1808, at the age of thirty-nine, Maria Franck married the eleven years younger [[engraver]] [[Johan Gustav Ruckman]] (1783–1862). Some encyclopedias therefore list her as Kristina Ruckman, as this was her name during the last ten years of her career. She became the mother of the painter [[Maria Ruckman]] (1810–1896). In contrast to most actors of her generation, which often had financial problems, Maria Franck was reportedly well off during her retirement, although this may have been in part because of her husband, who was a successful engraver.
===Roles===
Among her parts were "One of the pleasures" in ''Armide'' by Gluck (season 1786–87), Maria in ''Gustaf Adolf och Ebba Brahe'' (Gustaf Adolf and Ebba Brahe) by Gustav III (1787–88), Flattery in ''Alcides inträde i världen'' (The arrival of Alcide in to the world) by [[Johann Christian Friedrich Hæffner|Haeffner]] (1793–94), Theodora in ''De gamla friarna'' (The old suitors) by Dalayrac (1795–96), Antiope in ''Renaud'' by Haeffner (1800–01), Sabina in ''Den förmente prinsen'' (The supposed Prince) (1807–08), Madame de Veronne in ''Ambroise'' (1812–13), Gertrud in ''Den Schweiziska familjen'' (The Swiss family) (1815–16) and the abbess in ''Nunnorna'' (The [[nun]]s).
Her most noted performances was Thilda in ''Oden'', Celestina and the [[Abess]] in ''Korsfararne'' (Crusaders) by Kotzebue, and the leading parts in ''Virginia'' by Paykull, ''Johanna af Montfaucon'' by Kotzebue and Mrs Dorsan in ''Den svartsjuka hustrun'' (The jealous wife); the latest one (1808) was considered to be her greatest triumph.
==References== <references/> * [http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0165.html Anteckningar om svenska qvinnor] {{sv icon}} * [http://runeberg.org/nfam/0784.html Nordisk familjebok / 1800-talsutgåvan. 13. Pontin - Ruete] {{sv icon}} * Torsten Dahl: ''Svenska män och kvinnor. Nr 6'' ['Swedish men and women. Dictionary'] {{sv icon}} * Henrikson, Alf, Fram till Nybroplan: om Kungliga Dramatiska teatern, Wiken, Höganäs, 1988 {{ISBN|91-7024-445-6}} (in Swedish) * Österberg, Carin, Lewenhaupt, Inga & Wahlberg, Anna Greta, Svenska kvinnor: föregångare nyskapare, Signum, Lund, 1990 1990 (Swedish) * ''Kungliga teaterns repertoar 1773-1973'' ['Repertoire of the Royal Theatre 1773-1973'], 1974 (Swedish) * Nordensvan, Georg, Svensk teater och svenska skådespelare från Gustav III till våra dagar. Förra delen, 1772-1842, Bonnier, Stockholm, 1917 ['Swedish theatre and Swedish actors from Gustav III to our days. First book 1772–1842'] (Swedish)

revision.text:
{{lowercase|nferNelson}} '''nferNelson''' is the former name of GL Assessment, a leading independent provider of tests and other assessment services for [[education in the United Kingdom]]. Their products, which include assessments for the 0-19 age group, have a national reputation.
nferNelson were founded by the [[National Foundation for Educational Research]] (NFER), and became part of the [[Granada Learning]] Group in 2000.
In December 2007 NFER-Nelson's name was formally changed to GL Assessment
==External links== *[http://www.gl-assessment.co.uk/ GL Assessment Homepage]
[[Category:Educational assessment and evaluation]]
{{UK-edu-stub}}

revision.text:
'''The Pari Center for New Learning''' is a non-profit educational center located in the village of [[Pari, Civitella Paganico|Pari]] in [[Civitella Paganico]] of the [[Province of Grosseto]], Italy. The center was directed by [[F. David Peat]], who co-authored the book ''[[Science, Order, and Creativity]]'' with theoretical physicist [[David Bohm]].<ref>David Bohm, F. David Peat: ''Science, Order and Creativity'', 1987, Routledge, 2nd ed. 2000: {{ISBN|0-415-17182-2}}</ref> The center has hosted, with the support of its renowned ''fellows'' from [[academia]] and the arts, the academy ''Accademia dei Pari''. It hosts international conferences on the role of trust and ethics in the world of economics and business, and conferences on the relationship between religion and science.
== Origin and aims == It was created by F. David Peat and Maureen Doolan in 2000,<ref>[http://www.paricenter.com/biographies/doolan.php Maureen Doolan], biography, Pari Center</ref> with the support and assistance of external advisors, of the people of Pari, of Pari's village association Sette Colli and of the ''comune di Civitella-Paganico''.
The center is dedicated to education, learning and research and fosters an [[interdisciplinary]] approach linking science, the arts, ethics and spirituality. Above all, the Pari Center for New Learning is dedicated to the principle of "the [[spirit of place]]".<ref name="aboutpari">[http://www.paricenter.com/programs/courses/about%20Pari.php The Pari Center for New Learning] (downloaded 17 March 2012)</ref> Its location in a [[medieval]] village provides a setting for visitors of the center to pause and think about the future and the values, meaning and direction of [[contemporary society]]. The founders intend the wooded countryside and traditional farming methods in the surroundings of the center to draw attention to the importance of [[ecology|ecological]] considerations in comparison to progress and [[consumerism]].<ref name="aboutpari"/>
The Pari Center takes a "gentle" approach to learning, emphasizing human interaction in simple, pleasant surroundings without the intrusion of unnecessary technology. The underlying philosophy and approach is that of ''[[F. David Peat#Gentle Action|Gentle Action]]'' laid out in the book by David Peat of the same title.<ref>F. David Peat: ''Gentle Action: Bringing creative change to a turbulent world'', Pari Publishing, 2008, {{ISBN|978-88-95604-03-9}}</ref>
== Activities == The center's activities include residential courses and conferences that reflect the Center's philosophy, opportunities for scholars and researchers to spend extended periods in Pari as well as [[mentoring]] given by David Peat and other members of the Center's faculty.
The center hosts several courses or seminars every year.
It has hosted the ''Accademia dei Pari'', the name of which has a double meaning in Italian language, signifying both the ''academy of the people of Pari'' and ''the academy of equals''. The fellows of the academy include theoretical physicist [[Basil Hiley]] who collaborated over decades with David Bohm, art historian [[Deborah Klimburg-Salter]] who has studied the impact of the [[Sanghata Sutra]], theoretical physicist [[Ignazio Licata]], astronomer and space scientist [[Roger Malina]], physicist [[Roy McWeeny]] and [[Paavo Pylkkänen]] who has published articles on [[consciousness]] with Basil Hiley.<ref>[http://www.paricenter.com/accademia/fellows/index.php Fellows of the Accademia dei Pari], Pari Center</ref>
It has run international conferences on the role of trust and ethics in the world of economics and business<ref>[http://ethics.paricenter.com/en/conference/papers/papers02 Ethical choices in society, the economy, and the environment], May 5–6, Siena, Italy. ''Etica, Finanza ad Ambiente'' and ''Pari Center for New Learning'' (downloaded 17 March 2012)</ref> as well as conferences on the [[relationship between religion and science]]; one of these is documented in the book ''The Pari Dialogues: Essays in Science, Religion, Society and the Arts'' of 2008 by F. David Peat.<ref>F. David peat: ''The Pari Dialogues: Essays in Science, Religion, Society and the Arts'', 2008, {{ISBN|978-88-901960-5-8}}</ref>
In June 2008, the Pari Center for New Learning hosted a conference on ''The Legacy of David Bohm'', which included many collaborators and early students of Bohm as participants.<ref>See for example the characterization of their work together by Joseph Jaworski in chapter "Journey to Pari" of his book ''Source: The Inner Path of Knowledge Creation'', Berrett-Koehler Publishers, 2012</ref>
Along with organisations in Berlin, London, Stockholm, Tromso and Lisbon, the Pari Center for New Learning is partner in the project ''UniGrowCity'', for which it hosted a members' meeting in November 2011.<ref>[http://www.paricenter.com/library/papers/unigrowcityreport.php ''Unigrowcity: experience based learning for a more sustainable city of the future''], Report, Pari Center for New Learning</ref><ref>[http://www.unigrowcity.org/pari-meeting/ Pari Meeting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514093228/http://www.unigrowcity.org/pari-meeting/ |date=2013-05-14 }}, November 12, 2011</ref> The project, intended to address experienced-based learning for a more [[sustainable city]] of the future, was initiated by six organisations in six European countries and is part of the [[Grundtvig programme]] on [[adult education]].<ref>[http://www.programmallp.it/lkmw_file/LLP///Esiti%202011/GRU_esiti_partenariati_%202011_agosto.pdf GRUNDTVIG partenariatidi apprendimento 2011], Lifelong Learning Programme (LLP) (in Italian language)</ref><ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/education/lifelong-learning-programme/doc86_en.htm Grundtvig: practical learning for adults], European Commission</ref>
The center is associated with ''Pari Publishing'', a small [[publishing house]] specialized in science, religion, society, psychology, linguistics and the arts, managed by Eleanor Peat.<ref>[http://www.shantena.com/en/paricenter/ Shantena: Pari Center for New Learning]</ref><ref>[http://www.paripublishing.com/en/home Pari Publishing] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715044235/http://www.paripublishing.com/en/home |date=2011-07-15 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.paripublishing.com/en/about/who Who we are] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715044611/http://www.paripublishing.com/en/about/who |date=2011-07-15 }}, Pari Publishing</ref>
== Awards == Three times in 2003, 2004 and 2006, the Pari Dialogues hosted by the Pari Center for New Learning were awarded the ''Local Societies Initiative Supplemental Grant Award'' by the [[Metanexus Institute]].<ref>[http://www.metanexus.net/resources/networks/europe?page=2 Pari Dialogues on Religion and Science, Pari Center for New Learning, Pari, Grosseto], [[Metanexus Institute]]</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
* Steve Wright: [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/shi.155/abstract Organisation report Pari Center for New Learning], Spirituality and Health International, Volume 4, Issue 2, pages 16–17, June 2003, {{doi|10.1002/shi.155}} (Wiley Online 29 March 2006)
== External links == * [http://www.paricenter.com/ Pari Center for New Learning]
[[Category:Training organizations]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2000]]

The '''Perseus Project''' (version 4 also known as "Perseus Hopper")<ref name="home" /> is a [[digital library]] project of [[Tufts University]], which is located in Medford and Somerville, near [[Boston]], in the U.S. state of [[Massachusetts]]. The project assembles digital collections of [[humanities]] resources. It is hosted by the department of [[Classics]]. The project is [[mirror website|mirrored]] by the [[Max Planck Society]] in [[Berlin]], Germany,<ref>[http://perseus.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/ Berlin Perseus mirror] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127080511/http://perseus.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/ |date=2010-01-27 }}</ref> as well as by the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>[http://perseus.uchicago.edu/ Chicago Perseus mirror]</ref>
== History == The project was founded in 1987 to collect and present materials for the study of [[ancient Greece]]. It has published two [[CD-ROM]]s and established the Perseus Digital Library on the [[World Wide Web]] in 1995. The project has expanded its original scope; current collections cover Greco-Roman classics and the [[English Renaissance]]. Other materials, such as the papers of [[Edwin Bolles]] and the history of Tufts University, have been moved into the [[Tufts Digital Library]].
The editor-in-chief of the project is [[Gregory Crane]], the Tufts Winnick Family Chair in Technology and Entrepreneurship. He has held that position since the founding of the Perseus Project.
== Text format == Ancient Greek works in Perseus are stored as [[beta code]], although they may be reformatted for display into a variety of transcription systems.<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/Help/fonthelp.html Greek Font Display Help]</ref>
== Copyright status ==
The Perseus Project supports [[open-source content]],<ref>See Open Source section in the [http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20101008163722/http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/PR/perseus4.0.ann.full.html Perseus 4.0 Announcement]</ref> and it has published code on [[SourceForge]].<ref>[http://sourceforge.net/projects/perseus-artarch/ SourceForge.net: Perseus' Art and Archaeology Module]</ref> Perseus is a contributor to the [[Open Content Alliance]].<ref>[http://www.opencontentalliance.org/contributors/ List of Open Content Alliance contributors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091005051902/http://www.opencontentalliance.org/contributors/ |date=2009-10-05 }}</ref> The project also supports the [[Internet Archive]].
All texts and materials believed to be in the public domain are available for free download in [[XML]] format from Perseus 4.0.<ref name="home">[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper Perseus Digital Library]</ref> For a specific example, see the download and license information for [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text.jsp?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0136 Murray's translation of Homer's ''Odyssey'']. Some content is restricted by [[intellectual property]] [[license#Intellectual property|license]] agreements with the holders of the rights to that material.
== See also ==
* [[List of digital library projects]] * [[Stoa Consortium]] * [[Digital Classicist]] * [[A Greek-English Lexicon]] * [[Thesaurus Linguae Graecae]] * [[Herculaneum papyri]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Literature == * ''Ancient Greece from Prehistoric to Hellenistic Times'' by Thomas R. Martin, [[Yale University Press]], 1996. {{ISBN|0-300-06956-1}}. A text written by Professor Martin to accompany the Perseus Project online resources.
== External links == * [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/# The Perseus Project] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100127080511/http://perseus.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/ The Perseus Project (alternative interface)]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{See also|Postgraduate Training in Education (disambiguation)}} The '''Postgraduate Diploma in Education''' ('''PGDE'''), also known as a '''Graduate Diploma of Education''' ('''GradDipEd'''), is a one-year postgraduate course in several countries including [[Australia]], [[Ghana]], [[New Zealand]], [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Scotland]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Singapore]] and [[Zimbabwe]] for existing [[bachelor's degree]] holders leading to become a qualified teacher.
The [[professional certification|qualification]] is normally taught at a [[university]] or other [[higher education]] institution, though much of the course time is spent on placements in local schools. For example, in the Hong Kong programmes, most schools will have lesson time for about 20 weeks, and another 14 weeks (usually taken in 6 weeks for the first semester and 8 weeks for the second semester) for placements.
In [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], the former ''Higher Diploma in Education'' (H.Dip.Ed.) was renamed as the PGDE from 2007 onwards.
The [[Postgraduate Certificate in Education]] (PGCE) is the equivalent of the PGDE in [[England]], [[Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]] and historically in [[Scotland]]. Some universities, for instance [[Durham University]] award PGDE on successful completion of 120 University Credit Units (UCU) of a Master of Arts Education course (i.e., completing two years). The PGCE is awarded after 60UCUs.
==See also== *[[Professional Graduate Diploma in Education]] *[[Postgraduate diploma]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Postgraduate Diploma In Education}} [[Category:Professional titles and certifications]] [[Category:Educational qualifications in Scotland]] [[Category:Teacher training]]
{{Edu-stub}}

A '''preschool teacher''' is a type of [[early childhood educator]] who instructs children from 2 to age 4, which stands as the youngest stretch of [[early childhood education]]. Early Childhood Education teachers need to span the continuum of children from birth to age 8.
Preschool teachers are encouraged to hold credentials in Early Childhood Education in the form of a Child Development Accreditation (CDA) or formal college education in Early Childhood or a related subject.
The term "preschool" refers to instruction in non-public arenas such as licensed [[preschool]]s, [[childcare]] centers, [[family day care]] centers, [[home day care]] centers, center-based programs, federal programs like [[Head Start Program|Head Start]], and full or part-day private child centers or day care centers sponsored by religious bodies. The term "[[pre-kindergarten]]" refers to those lead teachers who offer instruction in a program for four-year-olds funded as part of the state public school system.
Preschool teachers must be able to work well and interact with young children, sometimes as young as 2 years 9 months. Preschool children have a short [[attention span]] and their worries are usually fairly simple. Most preschoolers are loving, affectionate, and playful, and like to play games, be read to, or play with toys.
==See also== * [[Early childhood education]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{refimprove|date=February 2008}}
[[Category:Education and training occupations]] [[Category:Early childhood education]] [[Category:People who work with children]]
